messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 47 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Most Classic Problems Remain NP-hard on Relative Neighborhood Graphs and their Relatives1footnote 11footnote 1This work is based on the first author‚Äôs master thesis.

Paper Abstract: Abstract Proximity graphs have been studied for several decades, motivated by applications in computational geometry, geography, data mining, and many other fields. However, the computational complexity of classic graph problems on proximity graphs mostly remained open. We now study 3-Colorability, Dominating Set, Feedback Vertex Set, Hamiltonian Cycle, and Independent Set on the proximity graph classes relative neighborhood graphs, Gabriel graphs, and relatively closest graphs. We prove that all of the problems remain NPNP\operatorname{NP}-hard on these graphs, except for 3-Colorability and Hamiltonian Cycle on relatively closest graphs, where the former is trivial and the latter is left open. Moreover, for every NPNP\operatorname{NP}-hard case we additionally show that no 2o‚Äã(n1/4)superscript2ùëúsuperscriptùëõ142^{o(n^{1/4})}-time algorithm exists unless the ETH fails, where nùëõn denotes the number of vertices.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 47 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 47"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Developing proximity graphs by Physarum polycephalum: Does the plasmodium follow the Toussaint hierarchy?",
        "Fixed parameter algorithms for dominating set and related problems on planar graphs",
        "Using relative neighborhood graphs for reliable database synchronization in manets",
        "Approximation algorithms for NP-complete problems on planar graphs",
        "Two-page book embeddings of 4-planar graphs",
        "Computational Geometry",
        "On disjoint cycles",
        "Proximity graphs: Eùê∏E, Œ¥ùõø\\delta, ŒîŒî\\Delta, œáùúí\\chi and œâùúî\\omega",
        "Characterizing proximity trees",
        "Selected open problems in graph drawing",
        "On colouring the nodes of a network",
        "Empty region graphs",
        "On parameterized exponential time complexity",
        "Proximity graphs for crowd movement sensors",
        "Coloring proximity graphs",
        "Coloring certain proximity graphs",
        "Properties of some Euclidean proximity graphs",
        "Relative neighborhood graphs uncover the dynamics of social media engagement",
        "Graph Theory",
        "Finding Hamiltonian cycles in Delaunay triangulations is NPNP\\operatorname{NP}-complete",
        "Fundamentals of Parameterized Complexity",
        "Nearest neighbour graph realizability is NP-hard",
        "A new statistical approach to geographic variation analysis",
        "The rectilinear Steiner tree problem is NP-complete",
        "Some simplified NP-complete graph problems",
        "The planar Hamiltonian circuit problem is NP-complete",
        "Computers and Intractability",
        "Gr√∂tzsch‚Äôs theorem on 333-colorings",
        "Navigating the semantic horizon using relative neighborhood graphs",
        "On the complexity of kùëòk-SAT",
        "Relative neighborhood graphs and their relatives",
        "The NP-completeness column: An ongoing guide",
        "Wavelength conversion in optical networks",
        "Regionalization: Theory and alternative algorithms",
        "Lower bounds based on the exponential time hypothesis",
        "Three short proofs in graph theory",
        "Properties of Gabriel graphs relevant to geographic variation research and the clustering of points in the plane",
        "Proximity algorithms",
        "Energy-efficient unicast and multicast communication for wireless ad hoc networks using multiple criteria",
        "Efficiently four-coloring planar graphs",
        "Untersuchungen zum Feedback Vertex Set Problem in ungerichteten Graphen [Investigations into the Feedback Vertex Set Problem in Undirected Graphs]",
        "The relative neighbourhood graph of a finite planar set",
        "Applications of the relative neighbourhood graph",
        "On the nonseparating independent set problem and feedback set problem for graphs with no vertex degree exceeding three",
        "Some properties of the planar Euclidean relative neighbourhood graph",
        "A study on analyzing the grid road network patterns using relative neighborhood graph",
        "Learning image-specific attributes by hyperbolic neighborhood graph propagation"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 47 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Most Classic Problems Remain NP-hard on Relative Neighborhood Graphs and their Relatives1footnote 11footnote 1This work is based on the first author‚Äôs master thesis., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
